content.question:
An aircraft is flying along a true course of 276º and the actual wind is different than the forecast wind. The forecast wind is 240/15 and the actual wind is 290/25. The airspeed remains the same. Which statements are correct or incorrect?
1) The lower ground speed will result in a later time of arrival.
2) The wind correction angle will change from a value to the right to a value to the left.

key_points: 1) "The lower ground speed will result in a later time of arrival

" Correct: With the actual wind coming from 290 degrees at 25 kt (instead of 240/15), while the aircraft is heading along a true course of 276º, it means that the aircraft is flying somewhat into a stronger headwind component (and weaker crosswind)
This stronger headwind component will reduce the ground speed
learning.explanation: 1) "The lower ground speed will result in a later time of arrival." Correct: With the actual wind coming from 290 degrees at 25 kt (instead of 240/15), while the aircraft is heading along a true course of 276º, it means that the aircraft is flying somewhat into a stronger headwind component (and weaker crosswind). This stronger headwind component will reduce the ground speed. A lower ground speed means it will take more time to cover the same distance, resulting in a later time of arrival. 2) "The wind correction angle will change from a value to the right to a value to the left." Incorrect: The change in wind direction and speed from the forecast (240/15) to the actual (290/25) wind means the wind correction angle will likely change. The wind correction angle is the angle by which the pilot adjusts the heading to compensate for the crosswind component of the wind. Under the forecasted wind, the wind is causing the aircraft to drift to the right, necessitating a wind correction angle to the left. In contrast, with the wind now arriving from the right of the aircraft, it will tend to push the aircraft to the left, thereby requiring a wind correction angle to the right.

content.question: The minimum climb gradient for obstacle clearance is 4%. TAS for the best rate of climb is 230 kt. Given a tailwind of 15 kt, what minimum rate of climb can be achieved?

key_points: Rate of climb is independent of wind, only climb angle (and flight path climb gradient) will be affected by a headwind or tailwind
It means you will reach a specific altitude in the same time interval, but your ground distance will be affected
HOWEVER, for obstacle clearance purposes, wind should be taken into consideration
learning.explanation: Rate of climb is independent of wind, only climb angle (and flight path climb gradient) will be affected by a headwind or tailwind. It means you will reach a specific altitude in the same time interval, but your ground distance will be affected. HOWEVER, for obstacle clearance purposes, wind should be taken into consideration. Therefore, we have: Rate of climb (ft/min) = Climb Gradient (%) x GS (kt) We can assume ROC remains constant even if we experience a tailwind of 15 kt. Rate of climb (ft/min) = Climb Gradient (%) x GS (kt) If we convert GS unit from kt to ft/min → 245 kt x 6 080 ft / 60 min = 24 827 ft/min Rate of climb (ft/min) = 4% x 24 827 ft/min = 993 ft/min

An aircraft is flying VFR using a VOR to navigate. The aircraft is following Radial 128º outbound from the VOR. Determine the expected Wind Correction Angle (WCA), given:
Wind: 080º (T)/35 kt
TAS: 155 kt
Variation: 15º W

key_points: The aircraft is following radial 128º => 128º Magnetic Track

Let’s start by converting Magnetic Track into True Track: Variation 15ºW: Variation West => Magnetic BEST True Track = Magnetic Track – Variation = 128º - 015º = 113º Solving from Heading (HDG) & Ground Speed (GS), knowing WV, TAS and required track
Set wind direction to 080º under the "TRUE HEADING" index at the top
learning.explanation: The aircraft is following radial 128º => 128º Magnetic Track. Let’s start by converting Magnetic Track into True Track: Variation 15ºW: Variation West => Magnetic BEST True Track = Magnetic Track – Variation = 128º - 015º = 113º Solving from Heading (HDG) & Ground Speed (GS), knowing WV, TAS and required track. Set wind direction to 080º under the "TRUE HEADING" index at the top. Set the center point on the True Airspeed (TAS) of 155 kt. Mark the wind velocity 35 kt down from the centre point. Initially, set the True Track to 113º under the "TRUE HEADING" index. Note that this heading would result in 9ºR drift and a track of 122º. Reduce the heading value under the index until the heading plus the drift gives a track of 113º. This occurs at a heading of 104º with 7ºR drift. The groundspeed for this track is approximately 124 kt. Wind correction angle (WCA) is the angle (º) between the Course and the Heading that is required for the aircraft to track that Course when there is wind. Wind Correction Angle is the same value as drift but it is applied in the opposite sense: (-)7ºL WCA

You are about to take a VFR flight in Summer with no serviceable radio aids on board your aircraft. The flight is likely to occur in haze in the late afternoon, with the Sun deteriorating visibility even more. Which route should you plan to take?

key_points: VFR navigation is highly affected by the choice of route, and particularly features to use for turning points or tracking

In this case, with quite poor visibility, due to the haze and the Sun to the West, the best way to navigate given here is to use the large line features of the highway and the river, which can be followed all the way to the destination
It does not add too much distance to the route, but does make sure that the pilot will always know their position and will not become lost or disorientated
learning.explanation: VFR navigation is highly affected by the choice of route, and particularly features to use for turning points or tracking. In this case, with quite poor visibility, due to the haze and the Sun to the West, the best way to navigate given here is to use the large line features of the highway and the river, which can be followed all the way to the destination. It does not add too much distance to the route, but does make sure that the pilot will always know their position and will not become lost or disorientated. The VOR cannot be used for navigation due to the lack of serviceable equipment on the aircraft. The tall mast may be an acceptable turning point, but might be difficult to identify in the Sun and the haze, and the long legs with reduced visibility could lead the aircraft to being off course and have a higher chance of getting the pilot lost than following the highway and river. The 4th route is not even on the map, and is similar to using the mast, though it is much likely easier to find, but is large and therefore less accurate as a position fix.

content.question:
Given the following information, what is the expected leg time?
Leg track : 090°
Distance : 100 NM
TAS : 350 kt
Wind : 030°/100 kt

key_points: First step of our calculation is going to involve the calculation of the head/tailwind component
Knowing our true course and the wind, we can easily calculate the wind components using a formula: cos (wind angle) × wind speed
In our case the course = 090° and the wind is reported at 030° / 100 kts
learning.explanation: First step of our calculation is going to involve the calculation of the head/tailwind component. Knowing our true course and the wind, we can easily calculate the wind components using a formula: cos (wind angle) × wind speed. In our case the course = 090° and the wind is reported at 030° / 100 kts. Therefore, the wind angle is 60° (90° - 030°). Wind component = cos 60° = 0.5 * 100 =50 kts headwind GS = TAS - HW => 350 - 50 = 300 kts Distance = Speed * Time 100 = 300 * t => 0.33 h * 60 =20 minutes Closest answer is 21 minutes.

content.question:
An aircraft is flying under VFR on a track of 168°M. The elevation of the highest obstacle within 5 NM of the intended track of the aircraft is 4200 ft. Given the following information, provided by an aerodrome at 1400 ft elevation, what is the minimum flight level which will give an obstacle clearance 1000 ft?
QNH: 1026 hPa
Temperature: 12°C below ISA
Assume 1 hPa = 30 ft

key_points: This is a typical "Altimetry Error question", which requires both pressure and temperature correction: The Minimum True Altitude to clear the obstacle is: 4200 ft + 1000 ft = 5200 ft
The ISA deviation is given: -12oC

After applying the temperature correction, the minimum true altitude will be: Min True Altitude - [4 x (True Altitude from Pressure Datum/1000) x ISA deviation] = 5200 ft - [4 x (5200 ft - 1400 ft)/1000) x (-12oC)] = 5200 ft + 182 ft = 5382 ft
learning.explanation: This is a typical "Altimetry Error question", which requires both pressure and temperature correction: The Minimum True Altitude to clear the obstacle is: 4200 ft + 1000 ft = 5200 ft. The ISA deviation is given: -12oC. After applying the temperature correction, the minimum true altitude will be: Min True Altitude - [4 x (True Altitude from Pressure Datum/1000) x ISA deviation] = 5200 ft - [4 x (5200 ft - 1400 ft)/1000) x (-12oC)] = 5200 ft + 182 ft = 5382 ft. After applying the pressure correction, the minimum pressure altitude will be: 5382 ft + [(1013 hPa - QNH) x 30 ft] = 5382 ft + [(1013 hPa - 1026 hPa) x 30 ft] = 5382 ft - (13 hPa x 30 ft) = 5382 ft - 390 ft = 4992 ft. According to the "ICAO VFR Semi-Circular Rule": For Easterly Magnetic tracks (000o - 179o), the Flight Levels are: Odd FLs + 500 ft (FL35, FL55, FL75, etc.). For Westerly Magnetic tracks (180o - 359o), the Flight Levels are: Even FLs + 500 ft (FL25, FL45, FL65, etc.). The aircraft flies an easterly magnetic track of 168o(M), thus the Minimum Flight Level, which provides obstacle clearance, after both pressure and temperature correction, that must be selected is: FL55.

content.question: Along the route the highest obstacle is 13 421 feet AMSL. If the QNH is 989 hPa, the MT is 311° and the temperature is 10 degrees below ISA, the lowest appropriate VFR flight level that you could choose in order to clear this obstacle by a minimum of 2000 feet is:

key_points: You need to fly 2 000 ft above an obstacle, 13 421 ft AMSL
Therefore, you need to fly at a True Altitude of 15 421 ft AMSL

Knowing our True Altitude, let's find Indicated Altitude: Indicated Altitude = True Altitude + Temperature Correction + Pressure correction Temperature Correction Rule of thumb: correction of 4% for each 10ºC deviation from ISA ISA deviation = -10ºC
learning.explanation: You need to fly 2 000 ft above an obstacle, 13 421 ft AMSL. Therefore, you need to fly at a True Altitude of 15 421 ft AMSL. Knowing our True Altitude, let's find Indicated Altitude: Indicated Altitude = True Altitude + Temperature Correction + Pressure correction Temperature Correction Rule of thumb: correction of 4% for each 10ºC deviation from ISA ISA deviation = -10ºC. Therefore we will apply a correction of 4%. 15 421 ft x 4% = 617 ft As ISA deviation is negative (-10ºC), Indicated altitude is greater than True altitude. Indicated Altitude = 15 421 ft + 617 ft = 16 038 ft Pressure correction If the current QNH is 989 hPa, the difference to standard pressure will be: 1013 hPa – 989 hPa = 24 hPa Assuming a barometric lapse rate of 30ft/hPa: 24 hPa x 30 ft/hPa = 720 ft Since our current QNH is lower than standard, Indicated altitude is greater than True altitude: 16 038 ft + 720 ft = 16 758 ft. This altitude is also called Pressure altitude (PA). Remember that you are flying Westbound on a VFR flight - Therefore, your flight level should be EVEN and you should use the intermediate 500 ft => The Lowest usable flight level will be FL185 Further info on Cruising Levels: VFR and IFR aircraft are allocated different levels to fly at: IFR flights use whole 1000's of feet (e.g. 1000, 3000 etc. when flying eastbound, and 2000, 4000 etc. when flying westbound) VFR flights use the intermediate 500 ft. levels (e.g. 3500, 5500 etc. when flying eastbound and 4500, 6500 when flying westbound)

key_points: Calculation of terrain clearance and flight level Upon inspection of LOGI, we can see that it is situated between 4 different areas with different Grid MORAs (Minimum Off-Route Altitude)
We must take the highest Grid MORA, in order to ensure that we have a safe vertical separation
The aircraft must fly at 10 800 ft
learning.explanation: Calculation of terrain clearance and flight level Upon inspection of LOGI, we can see that it is situated between 4 different areas with different Grid MORAs (Minimum Off-Route Altitude). We must take the highest Grid MORA, in order to ensure that we have a safe vertical separation. The aircraft must fly at 10 800 ft. This must be the true altitude of the aircraft. This altitude must be corrected for any temperature ISA deviation and then any difference in pressure from standard (1013 hPa), to get the pressure altitude, allowing us to work out the lowest usable flight level. The first step is to determine the temperature correction. The ISA deviation is ISA -15°C. Based on the 4% rule and its calculation mentioned in the rules below, the height correction for the temperature can be calculated as follows: Height correction for temperature = 4 × (-15) × (10 800/1000) = -648 ft. The temperature correction is added to the true altitude as per the rules below, to give an indicated altitude of 11 448 ft. Next, we need to compute the pressure correction by considering the deviation from the standard mean sea level pressure of 1013 hPa: 1018 hPa - 1013 hPa = 5 hPa. Since the barometric lapse rate near the surface is 30 ft/hPa, the pressure correction can be calculated as follows: Pressure correction = (5) x 30 ft/hPa = 150 ft. This value needs to be subtracted from the indicated altitude as per the rules below: Pressure Altitude = 11 448 - 150 = 11 298 ft Since we are a VFR flight, we are required to fly at altitudes that are whole thousands plus 500 feet. The only altitude above 11 298 ft which also obeys this rule is FL115. RULES. The following rules should be considered for altimetry calculations: All calculations are based on rounded pressure values to the nearest lower hPa. The value for the barometric lapse rate between MSL and 500 hPa to be used is 30 ft/hPa as an acceptable approximation of the barometric lapse rate. To determine the true altitude/height, the following rule of thumb, called the ‘4 %-rule’, shall be used: the altitude/height changes by 4% for each 10°C temperature deviation from ISA. For simplification: Height correction for the temp = 4 × (ISA DEV) × Indicated alt/1000 = _____ ft If no further information is given, the deviation of the outside-air temperature from ISA is considered to be the same throughout the whole layer. The elevation of the aerodrome has to be taken into account. The temperature correction has to be considered for the layer between the station (usually an aerodrome) and the position of the aircraft. HIGHER PRESSURE; INDICATED ALTITUDE > PRESSURE ALTITUDE LOWER PRESSURE; INDICATED ALTITUDE < PRESSURE ALTITUDE WARMER THAN ISA; TRUE ALTITUDE > INDICATED ALTITUDE COLDER THAN ISA; TRUE ALTITUDE < INDICATED ALTITUDE DEFINITIONS. Pressure Altitude: The altimeter indication with standard pressure (1013.2 hPa) set. Indicated Altitude: The altimeter indication with local QNH set. True altitude: The actual altitude of the aircraft above mean sea level.

content.question:
A mountain 6 011 ft AMSL will be crossed. What is the lowest VFR ICAO level the aircraft must fly to obtain a clearance of 2 000 ft? Given:
Variation: 10ºW
Aircraft's Track: 356º T
Aircraft's HDG: 355º M
QNH: 990 hPa
Assume 1 hPa = 30 ft

key_points: First considerations: To obtain a terrain clearance of 2 000 ft, the aircraft must be flown at a true altitude of = 6 011 ft + 2 000 ft = 8 011 ft When flying Flight Levels, the altimeter is set to Standard Pressure (1013 hPa)
Pressure Correction: Note: If QNH is higher than 1013 hPa => True Altitude is higher than IA
If QNH is lower than 1013 hPa => True Altitude is lower than IA
learning.explanation: First considerations: To obtain a terrain clearance of 2 000 ft, the aircraft must be flown at a true altitude of = 6 011 ft + 2 000 ft = 8 011 ft When flying Flight Levels, the altimeter is set to Standard Pressure (1013 hPa). Pressure Correction: Note: If QNH is higher than 1013 hPa => True Altitude is higher than IA. If QNH is lower than 1013 hPa => True Altitude is lower than IA. Local pressure equals 990 hPa which is lower than standard pressure by 1013 hPa - 990 hPa = 23 hPa. 23 hPa x 30 ft/hPa = 690 ft Indicated Altitude = True Altitude + Pressure Correction Indicated Altitude = 8 011 ft + 690 ft = 8 701 ft Semicircular Flight Rules: IFR flight levels/altitudes are divisible by 1 000 ft (i.e. 7 000 ft, 8 000 ft, 9 000 ft). The VFR rules of flight level and/or altitude selection is the same as IFR ones with adding 500 ft to all levels. The default worldwide semi-circular rule is the East/West orientation of the flight level parity: Your aircraft has track between 0° and 179°, your flight level or altitude must be odd; Your aircraft has track between 180° and 359°, your flight level or altitude must be even. The appropriate altitude or flight level must be determined using the magnetic track (not heading). In this case, True Track (TT) equals 356º, applying the magnetic Variation provided (10ºW), we can find the Magnetic Track (MT) Variation West, magnetic direction BEST; Variation East, Magnetic Direction LEAST. MT = 356º + 10º = 006º According to the rules shared above, an ODD flight level + 500 ft must be used: First available Flight level above 8 701 ft => FL95

Refer to ED-4 VFR chart from Jeppesen GSPRM 2017. An aircraft on a VFR flight intends to fly overhead aerodrome Straubing (EDMS) (48°54' N, 012°31' E). Given the following information, what is the minimum indicated altitude required to clear the Straubing (EDMS) Class F airspace by 500 ft?
Altimeter temperature error with an OAT -7°C at Straubing (EDMS): 240 ft
QNH at Straubing (EDMS): 998 hPa
Altimeter setting: 998 hPa
(Round altitudes and elevations to the nearest 10 ft)

key_points: The upper vertical limit of the Straubing (EDMS) Class F airspace is 2 500 ft Above Ground Level (AGL) and the aerodrome's elevation is 1 054 ft
The altimeter temperature error correction is given, 240 ft, because of flying within a cold atmosphere with an OAT of -7°C
The correction must be added, because the indicated altitude will be higher than the true altitude in a cold atmosphere
learning.explanation: The upper vertical limit of the Straubing (EDMS) Class F airspace is 2 500 ft Above Ground Level (AGL) and the aerodrome's elevation is 1 054 ft. The altimeter temperature error correction is given, 240 ft, because of flying within a cold atmosphere with an OAT of -7°C. The correction must be added, because the indicated altitude will be higher than the true altitude in a cold atmosphere. The aircraft flies with an altimeter setting, 998 hPa, equal to the QNH of the Straubing aerodrome, thus no pressure correction is required. Therefore, the minimum indicated altitude to clear the Straubing (EDMS) Class F airspace by 500 ft is: 2 500 ft + 1 054 ft + 240 ft + 500 ft = 4 294 ft.

content.question: Which of the following statements is correct? The climb gradient is:

options.A: Always smaller than the angle of climb.
options.B: Always larger than the angle of climb.
options.D: The same as the angle of climb.

key_points: Climb gradient is the ratio between distance travelled over the ground and altitude gained and is expressed as a percentage
The angle of climb can be defined as the angle between a horizontal plane representing the Earth's surface and the actual flight path followed by the aircraft during its ascent
The climb gradient numerical value is always larger than the angle of climb
learning.explanation: Climb gradient is the ratio between distance travelled over the ground and altitude gained and is expressed as a percentage. The angle of climb can be defined as the angle between a horizontal plane representing the Earth's surface and the actual flight path followed by the aircraft during its ascent. The climb gradient numerical value is always larger than the angle of climb. For instance, 3º angle of climb equals approximately 5% gradient.

content.question: Refer to VFR Chart ED-4 from the Jeppesen GSPRM 2017. A VFR flight is planned from Freiburg i. Br. airport (EDTF, N48°01.3’, E007°50.1’) to Offenburg airport (EDTO, N48°27.0’, E007°55.5’) at the lowest safe altitude. Which is the best visual reference landmark for drift and time deviation checks along the intended route?

options.A: The wind farm East off Altdorf-Wallburg (EDSW) airport.
options.C: The wind farm Southwest of Schweighausen town.
options.D: The unlighted tower North of Emmendingen town.

key_points: When planning a route, the pilot will use visual check points to monitor the flight progress along a flight leg
Choice of the ground features is critical, as things that show up well on maps, do not necessarily show up well from the air
Thus, the pilot, among others, should consider: Proximity to planned track: Ground features on or close to the track are preferred
learning.explanation: When planning a route, the pilot will use visual check points to monitor the flight progress along a flight leg. Choice of the ground features is critical, as things that show up well on maps, do not necessarily show up well from the air. Thus, the pilot, among others, should consider: Proximity to planned track: Ground features on or close to the track are preferred. Size and uniqueness: Large objects with colour contrast and/or some vertical extent will be easier to identify. Time of the year: Changes in vegetation or snow cover can cause the same landscape to take on a different appearance at different times of the year. Planned Altitude: At lower levels, a selected visual check point may be hidden by high ground or only visible after the aircraft has passed over it and for a limited period of time. Some of the problems faced by a pilot during VFR navigation at lower levels are the following: The horizon may be obscured by high ground, so attitude flying is difficult. Frequent changes may be needed to maintain the correct airspeed, while climbing or descending over undulating ground. The view ahead and around is restricted by the next fold of high ground. The angle at which you are looking becomes flatter and if a feature does not have some vertical extent (such as towers and wind farms), you are unlikely to see it at low level. A selected visual check point may be hidden by high ground or only visible after the aircraft has passed over it and for a limited period of time (such as a river). Thus, towers and wind farms are the most suitable ground features for low level VFR navigation. But, among them, the best ones are those which are along the route and as close to the departure airport as possible, because the pilot will be aware of any drift or time deviation at the initial stages of the cruise phase proceeding in minor recalculations. Therefore, the visual reference landmark which best covers the forementioned criteria is the unlighted tower North of the town of Emmendingen, with elevation of 1 384 ft. content.question:
You plan to fly over high terrain of 6 240 ft where a minimum clearance altitude of 2 000 ft is required. An airport nearby at an altitude of 1 240 ft reports a QNH of 1000 hPa and the OAT is ISA -12ºC. What is the lowest usable flight level?
(Assume: 1 hPa = 30 ft)

key_points: Calculation of terrain clearance and lowest usable flight level: The aircraft must fly at 8 240 ft (6 240 ft + 2 000 ft)
This altitude must be the true altitude of the aircraft

This altitude must be corrected for any temperature ISA deviation and then any difference in pressure from standard (1013 hPa), to get the pressure altitude, allowing us to work out the lowest usable flight level
learning.explanation: Calculation of terrain clearance and lowest usable flight level: The aircraft must fly at 8 240 ft (6 240 ft + 2 000 ft). This altitude must be the true altitude of the aircraft. This altitude must be corrected for any temperature ISA deviation and then any difference in pressure from standard (1013 hPa), to get the pressure altitude, allowing us to work out the lowest usable flight level. The first step is to determine the temperature correction. The ISA deviation is ISA -12ºC. For the temperature correction, the airfield elevation must be taken into account: 8 240 ft - 1 240 ft = 7 000 ft. Based on the 4% rule and its calculation mentioned in the rules below, the height correction for the temperature can be calculated as follows: Height correction for temperature = 4 × (-12) × (7 000/1000) = -336 ft. In this case, the temperature correction is added to the true altitude as per the rules below (refer to the table below), to give an indicated altitude of ­­8 576 ft. Next, we need to compute the pressure correction by considering the deviation from the standard mean sea level pressure of 1013 hPa: 1013 hPa - 1000 hPa = 13 hPa. Since the barometric lapse rate near the surface is 30 ft/hPa, the pressure correction can be calculated as follows: Pressure correction = 13 hPa x 30 ft/hPa = 390 ft. This value needs to be added to the indicated altitude as per the rules below: Pressure Altitude = 8 576 ft + 390 ft = 8 966 ft. Thus, the Minimum Flight Level, which provides obstacle clearance, after both pressure and temperature correction, that must be selected is: FL90. RULES. The following rules should be considered for altimetry calculations: All calculations are based on rounded pressure values to the nearest lower hPa. The value for the barometric lapse rate between MSL and 500 hPa to be used is 30 ft/hPa as an acceptable approximation of the barometric lapse rate. To determine the true altitude/height, the following rule of thumb, called the ‘4 %-rule’, shall be used: the altitude/height changes by 4% for each 10°C temperature deviation from ISA. For simplification: Height correction for the temp = 4 × (ISA DEV) × Indicated alt/1000 = ___ ft If no further information is given, the deviation of the outside-air temperature from ISA is considered to be the same throughout the whole layer. The elevation of the aerodrome has to be taken into account. The temperature correction has to be considered for the layer between the station (usually an aerodrome) and the position of the aircraft. HIGHER PRESSURE; INDICATED ALTITUDE > PRESSURE ALTITUDE LOWER PRESSURE; INDICATED ALTITUDE < PRESSURE ALTITUDE WARMER THAN ISA; TRUE ALTITUDE > INDICATED ALTITUDE COLDER THAN ISA; TRUE ALTITUDE < INDICATED ALTITUDE DEFINITIONS. Pressure Altitude: The altimeter indication with standard pressure (1013.2 hPa) set. Indicated Altitude: The altimeter indication with local QNH set. True altitude: The actual altitude of the aircraft above mean sea level.

content.question: A VFR flight is planned from aerodrome A to aerodrome B on a 085° track. What would be an appropriate Flight Level for this route?

key_points: In order to apply vertical separation, the ICAO VFR Semi-Circular Rule must be followed
The ICAO VFR semi-circular rule can be derived, which permits the selection of FLs, in accordance with aircraft’s magnetic track
Tracks are specified as being either ‘eastbound’ or ‘westbound’
learning.explanation: In order to apply vertical separation, the ICAO VFR Semi-Circular Rule must be followed. The ICAO VFR semi-circular rule can be derived, which permits the selection of FLs, in accordance with aircraft’s magnetic track. Tracks are specified as being either ‘eastbound’ or ‘westbound’. Eastbound tracks are 000°M - 179°M inclusive, and westbound, 180°M - 359°M inclusive. For the eastbound magnetic tracks we select Odd Fls + 500 ft (35,55,75, etc.). For the westbound magnetic tracks we select Even FLs + 500 ft (25,45,65, etc.). The question does not specify if the track is magnetic or true, but whichever the variation could be, the track still remains eastbound. Therefore, according to the ICAO VFR semi-circular rule, the FL that must be selected for 085° track is FL55.

For an aircraft flying VFR from Straubing (EDMS) aerodrome (N48°54.0’ E012°31.1’) to Linz international (LOWL) aerodrome (N48°14.1’ E014°11.3’), what is the best cruising altitude according to ICAO semi-circular rule, VFR checkpoint and ground navigational aid to tune to?

options.D: 7 000 ft; Power plant at Vilshofen; FRE VOR/DME.

key_points: Firstly, find the exact position of the two aerodromes, using the coordinates given, draw a straight line as a route between them and examine each statement carefully
Altitude selection: Before the route is recorded on the flight plan, we need to consider the altitude to fly at
The Minimum Grid Area Altitudes along the route are 5 400 ft, 7 200 ft and 4 100 ft
learning.explanation: Firstly, find the exact position of the two aerodromes, using the coordinates given, draw a straight line as a route between them and examine each statement carefully. Altitude selection: Before the route is recorded on the flight plan, we need to consider the altitude to fly at. The Minimum Grid Area Altitudes along the route are 5 400 ft, 7 200 ft and 4 100 ft. For this VFR flight, the minimum safe altitude along the whole route is 7 200 ft. But, we have to also consider the ICAO VFR cruising altitudes and select an appropriate altitude for this easterly magnetic track. According to the ICAO VFR semi-circular rule, for an easterly magnetic track, Odd FLs/Altitudes + 500 ft must be followed (3 500 ft, 5 500 ft, 7 500 ft, etc.). So, a cruise altitude of 7 500 ft can be followed, which apart from being according to the ICAO rule, it provides enough obstacle clearance too. In portions of the whole route, a lower altitude could be flown, 5 500 ft, but with less vertical obstacle clearance provided, probably poor comms signal and encountered turbulence. Ground feature selection: Line features, such as highways, which cross vertically the intended track are highly recommended as ground features for navigation in VFR flights. Both Highways, A3 and A92, as line features, are very helpful for groundspeed and timing checks, because they both cross vertically the track. But among them, the A3 highway is more preferred since it is almost halfway. Of course, the Power plant at Vilshofen (1 593 ft) could be selected as a VFR checkpoint, since it covers the criteria that should be considered for a VFR ground feature selection, but the question asks for the best. NavAid selection: Between the LNZ and FRE VOR/DME, the former is the best to tune to, even just after take-off (if both relief and VOR’s range permit), since it easily leads to the destination, almost directly, with an insignificant course deviation.

A pilot is planning a VFR flight from Ajaccio (LFKJ) to Marina Di Campo (LIRJ) aerodrome with alternate aerodrome the Grosseto (LIRS). Given the following information, what is the required time from Marina Di Campo to Grosseto?
Cruise distance from LIRJ to LIRS: 24 NM
Climb from LIRJ to cruise altitude: 3 minutes
Descent to LIRS: 4 minutes
Cruise TAS: 150 kt
Wind: 050°(T)/20 kt
Track from LIRJ to LIRS: 090°(T)

key_points: Firstly, find the Groundspeed using your flight/nav computer: Set wind direction 050°T under the True Index
Mark wind velocity 20 kt up from centre point
learning.explanation: 1. Firstly, find the Groundspeed using your flight/nav computer: Set wind direction 050°T under the True Index. Mark wind velocity 20 kt up from centre point. Set True Course 090°T under the True Index. Slide wind velocity mark to TAS 150 kt. Groundspeed reads below the centre dot 134 kt. 2. Calculate the Cruise Time from LIRJ to LIRS: Cruise distance / Groundspeed = 24 NM / 134 kt = 0.18 hr or 10.7 min. 3. The time required from the destination Marina Di Campo (LIRJ) aerodrome to the alternate aerodrome Grosseto (LIRS) is the sum of the following: Time to climb from LIRJ to cruising level/altitude, taking into account the expected departure routing: 3 min. Time to cruise from top of climb to top of descent, taking into account the expected routing: 10.7 min. Time to descent from top of descent to LIRS: 4 min. Thus, the time required is: 3 min + 10.7 min + 4 min = 17.7 min, closest answer 18 min. content.question: You want to plan a VFR flight within a controlled airspace using your GNSS flight plan as a back-up navigation method. Which of the following are best suited as significant points for entering into your GNSS flight plan as VFR waypoints using a distance and bearing?

key_points: The question is poorly worded as none of the answers in this question fit the criteria for visual fix points that can be defined by a distance and bearing from a known point, nor are they suitable as known points for creating a distance and bearing to a VFR waypoint
The only possible known point for defining a VFR waypoint via bearing and distance is the airport reference point (ARP)
An airport reference point (ARP) is a known and well-defined location on an airport used as a reference for navigation purposes
learning.explanation: The question is poorly worded as none of the answers in this question fit the criteria for visual fix points that can be defined by a distance and bearing from a known point, nor are they suitable as known points for creating a distance and bearing to a VFR waypoint. The only possible known point for defining a VFR waypoint via bearing and distance is the airport reference point (ARP). An airport reference point (ARP) is a known and well-defined location on an airport used as a reference for navigation purposes. Using the ARP as a waypoint in a GNSS flight plan provides a reliable and accurate navigation aid for VFR flights, especially when flying within controlled airspace. This is because the ARP is precisely located on aviation charts and is well-known to air traffic controllers, making it easier to communicate your position to ATC if necessary. Power lines, major cities and large towns, and coastlines may be visually identifiable landmarks that can assist with navigation, but they are not as precise and reliable as using an airport reference point. Additionally, power lines may not always be visible, and coastlines can be affected by changing weather conditions, tides, and other factors, making them less reliable as navigation aids. Major cities and large towns can be useful as general orientation points but may not provide the necessary precision needed for accurate navigation within a controlled airspace.

How many feet you have to climb to reach FL75? Given:
Departure aerodrome elevation 1500 ft
QNH = 1023 hPa
Temperature = ISA
1 hPa = 30 ft

key_points: One of the methods used to solve this question is to calculate True Altitude based on the provided Pressure Altitude - by correcting it for QNH deviation and for Temperature deviation
Note that in this case, temperature = ISA, therefore we can disregard the latter
Adjust for QNH deviation If QNH is higher than 1013 hPa => Indicated Altitude is lower than True Altitude
learning.explanation: One of the methods used to solve this question is to calculate True Altitude based on the provided Pressure Altitude - by correcting it for QNH deviation and for Temperature deviation. Note that in this case, temperature = ISA, therefore we can disregard the latter. Adjust for QNH deviation If QNH is higher than 1013 hPa => Indicated Altitude is lower than True Altitude. If QNH is lower than 1013 hPa => Indicated Altitude is higher than True Altitude. 1023 – 1013 = 10 hPa 10 hPa x 30 ft = 300 ft With regards to this question, QNH is 10 hPa higher than standard, therefore, True altitude is 30 hPa higher than IA => 7500 ft + 300 ft = 7 800 ft. When you climb from the airport with an elevation of 1 500 ft to True Altitude of 7 800 ft, you will climb 7800 - 1500 = 6300 ft.

content.question: An aircraft is flying at FL180, OAT -11°C, QNH 1003. What is the true altitude?

key_points: True altitude calculation from a Flight Level: In this question, we are given a pressure altitude (in the form of a flight level) and are asked for the terrain clearance, therefore we need to determine the corresponding true altitude
The first step is to compute the pressure correction by considering the deviation from the standard mean sea level pressure of 1013 hPa: 1013 hPa - 1003 hPa = 10 hPa
Since the barometric lapse rate near the surface is 30 ft/hPa, the pressure correction can be calculated as follows: Pressure correction = 10 hPa x 30 ft/hPa = ­­­300 ft
learning.explanation: True altitude calculation from a Flight Level: In this question, we are given a pressure altitude (in the form of a flight level) and are asked for the terrain clearance, therefore we need to determine the corresponding true altitude. The first step is to compute the pressure correction by considering the deviation from the standard mean sea level pressure of 1013 hPa: 1013 hPa - 1003 hPa = 10 hPa. Since the barometric lapse rate near the surface is 30 ft/hPa, the pressure correction can be calculated as follows: Pressure correction = 10 hPa x 30 ft/hPa = ­­­300 ft. This value needs to be subtracted from the pressure altitude as per the rules below: Indicated altitude = 18 000 ft - 300 ft = 17 700 ft. To determine the temperature correction, it is necessary to have knowledge of the ISA air temperature for the given flight level/altitude (FL250). In the International Standard Atmosphere (ISA), the air temperature at sea level is 15ºC, and the temperature lapse rate is -2ºC/1 000 ft. The formula to calculate the ISA temperature is therefore: ISA temperature = 15ºC - (18 000/1 000) x 2, giving an ISA temperature of ­­­-21 ºC. The actual outside air temperature is ­­­-11 ºC, which means we have an ISA deviation of ISA +10ºC. Next, we need to determine the temperature correction. The ISA deviation is ISA +10ºC. Based on the 4% rule and its calculation mentioned in the rules below, the height correction for the temperature can be calculated as follows: Height correction for temperature = 4 × (+10) × (17 700/1000) = + 708 ft. The temperature correction is added to the indicated altitude as per the rules below, to give a true altitude of 17 700 ft + 708 ft = 18 408 ft RULES. The following rules should be considered for altimetry calculations: All calculations are based on rounded pressure values to the nearest lower hPa. The value for the barometric lapse rate between MSL and 500 hPa to be used is 30 ft/hPa as an acceptable approximation of the barometric lapse rate (if not provided by the question). To determine the true altitude/height, the following rule of thumb, called the ‘4 %-rule’, shall be used: the altitude/height changes by 4% for each 10°C temperature deviation from ISA. For simplification: Height correction for the temp = 4 × (ISA DEV) × Indicated alt/1000 = ___ ft If no further information is given, the deviation of the outside-air temperature from ISA is considered to be the same throughout the whole layer. The elevation of the aerodrome has to be taken into account. The temperature correction has to be considered for the layer between the station (usually an aerodrome) and the position of the aircraft. HIGHER PRESSURE; INDICATED ALTITUDE > PRESSURE ALTITUDE LOWER PRESSURE; INDICATED ALTITUDE < PRESSURE ALTITUDE WARMER THAN ISA; TRUE ALTITUDE > INDICATED ALTITUDE COLDER THAN ISA; TRUE ALTITUDE < INDICATED ALTITUDE DEFINITIONS. Pressure Altitude: The altimeter indication with standard pressure (1013.2 hPa) set. Indicated Altitude: The altimeter indication with local QNH set. True altitude: The actual altitude of the aircraft above mean sea level.

content.question:
An aircraft is flying along a true course of 276º and the actual wind is different than the forecast wind. The forecast wind is 240/15 and the actual wind is 290/25. The airspeed remains the same. Which statements are correct or incorrect?
1) The lower ground speed will result in a later time of arrival.
2) The wind correction angle will change from a value to the right to a value to the left.

key_points: 1) "The lower ground speed will result in a later time of arrival

" Correct: With the actual wind coming from 290 degrees at 25 kt (instead of 240/15), while the aircraft is heading along a true course of 276º, it means that the aircraft is flying somewhat into a stronger headwind component (and weaker crosswind)
This stronger headwind component will reduce the ground speed
learning.explanation: 1) "The lower ground speed will result in a later time of arrival." Correct: With the actual wind coming from 290 degrees at 25 kt (instead of 240/15), while the aircraft is heading along a true course of 276º, it means that the aircraft is flying somewhat into a stronger headwind component (and weaker crosswind). This stronger headwind component will reduce the ground speed. A lower ground speed means it will take more time to cover the same distance, resulting in a later time of arrival. 2) "The wind correction angle will change from a value to the right to a value to the left." Incorrect: The change in wind direction and speed from the forecast (240/15) to the actual (290/25) wind means the wind correction angle will likely change. The wind correction angle is the angle by which the pilot adjusts the heading to compensate for the crosswind component of the wind. Under the forecasted wind, the wind is causing the aircraft to drift to the right, necessitating a wind correction angle to the left. In contrast, with the wind now arriving from the right of the aircraft, it will tend to push the aircraft to the left, thereby requiring a wind correction angle to the right.

Therefore, we have: Rate of climb (ft/min) = Climb Gradient (%) x GS (kt) We can assume ROC remains constant even if we experience a tailwind of 15 kt. Rate of climb (ft/min) = Climb Gradient (%) x GS (kt) If we convert GS unit from kt to ft/min → 245 kt x 6 080 ft / 60 min = 24 827 ft/min Rate of climb (ft/min) = 4% x 24 827 ft/min = 993 ft/min

learning.explanation: First step of our calculation is going to involve the calculation of the head/tailwind component. content.question:
An aircraft is flying under VFR on a track of 168°M. The elevation of the highest obstacle within 5 NM of the intended track of the aircraft is 4200 ft. Given the following information, provided by an aerodrome at 1400 ft elevation, what is the minimum flight level which will give an obstacle clearance 1000 ft?
QNH: 1026 hPa
Temperature: 12°C below ISA
Assume 1 hPa = 30 ft

key_points: This is a typical "Altimetry Error question", which requires both pressure and temperature correction: The Minimum True Altitude to clear the obstacle is: 4200 ft + 1000 ft = 5200 ft
The ISA deviation is given: -12oC

After applying the temperature correction, the minimum true altitude will be: Min True Altitude - [4 x (True Altitude from Pressure Datum/1000) x ISA deviation] = 5200 ft - [4 x (5200 ft - 1400 ft)/1000) x (-12oC)] = 5200 ft + 182 ft = 5382 ft
learning.explanation: This is a typical "Altimetry Error question", which requires both pressure and temperature correction: The Minimum True Altitude to clear the obstacle is: 4200 ft + 1000 ft = 5200 ft. The ISA deviation is given: -12oC. After applying the temperature correction, the minimum true altitude will be: Min True Altitude - [4 x (True Altitude from Pressure Datum/1000) x ISA deviation] = 5200 ft - [4 x (5200 ft - 1400 ft)/1000) x (-12oC)] = 5200 ft + 182 ft = 5382 ft. After applying the pressure correction, the minimum pressure altitude will be: 5382 ft + [(1013 hPa - QNH) x 30 ft] = 5382 ft + [(1013 hPa - 1026 hPa) x 30 ft] = 5382 ft - (13 hPa x 30 ft) = 5382 ft - 390 ft = 4992 ft. According to the "ICAO VFR Semi-Circular Rule": For Easterly Magnetic tracks (000o - 179o), the Flight Levels are: Odd FLs + 500 ft (FL35, FL55, FL75, etc.). For Westerly Magnetic tracks (180o - 359o), the Flight Levels are: Even FLs + 500 ft (FL25, FL45, FL65, etc.). The aircraft flies an easterly magnetic track of 168o(M), thus the Minimum Flight Level, which provides obstacle clearance, after both pressure and temperature correction, that must be selected is: FL55.

content.question: Along the route the highest obstacle is 13 421 feet AMSL. If the QNH is 989 hPa, the MT is 311° and the temperature is 10 degrees below ISA, the lowest appropriate VFR flight level that you could choose in order to clear this obstacle by a minimum of 2000 feet is:

key_points: You need to fly 2 000 ft above an obstacle, 13 421 ft AMSL
Therefore, you need to fly at a True Altitude of 15 421 ft AMSL

Knowing our True Altitude, let's find Indicated Altitude: Indicated Altitude = True Altitude + Temperature Correction + Pressure correction Temperature Correction Rule of thumb: correction of 4% for each 10ºC deviation from ISA ISA deviation = -10ºC
learning.explanation: You need to fly 2 000 ft above an obstacle, 13 421 ft AMSL. Therefore, you need to fly at a True Altitude of 15 421 ft AMSL. Knowing our True Altitude, let's find Indicated Altitude: Indicated Altitude = True Altitude + Temperature Correction + Pressure correction Temperature Correction Rule of thumb: correction of 4% for each 10ºC deviation from ISA ISA deviation = -10ºC. Therefore we will apply a correction of 4%. 15 421 ft x 4% = 617 ft As ISA deviation is negative (-10ºC), Indicated altitude is greater than True altitude. Indicated Altitude = 15 421 ft + 617 ft = 16 038 ft Pressure correction If the current QNH is 989 hPa, the difference to standard pressure will be: 1013 hPa – 989 hPa = 24 hPa Assuming a barometric lapse rate of 30ft/hPa: 24 hPa x 30 ft/hPa = 720 ft Since our current QNH is lower than standard, Indicated altitude is greater than True altitude: 16 038 ft + 720 ft = 16 758 ft. This altitude is also called Pressure altitude (PA). Remember that you are flying Westbound on a VFR flight - Therefore, your flight level should be EVEN and you should use the intermediate 500 ft => The Lowest usable flight level will be FL185 Further info on Cruising Levels: VFR and IFR aircraft are allocated different levels to fly at: IFR flights use whole 1000's of feet (e.g. 1000, 3000 etc. when flying eastbound, and 2000, 4000 etc. when flying westbound) VFR flights use the intermediate 500 ft. levels (e.g. 3500, 5500 etc. when flying eastbound and 4500, 6500 when flying westbound)

An aircraft is doing some aerial work while flying VFR in the vicinity of LOGI (N47°29.7' E014°29.9'). Which flight level is most suitable for the activity?
Temperature = ISA -15°C
QNH = 1018 hPa

key_points: Calculation of terrain clearance and flight level Upon inspection of LOGI, we can see that it is situated between 4 different areas with different Grid MORAs (Minimum Off-Route Altitude)
We must take the highest Grid MORA, in order to ensure that we have a safe vertical separation
The aircraft must fly at 10 800 ft
learning.explanation: Calculation of terrain clearance and flight level Upon inspection of LOGI, we can see that it is situated between 4 different areas with different Grid MORAs (Minimum Off-Route Altitude). We must take the highest Grid MORA, in order to ensure that we have a safe vertical separation. The aircraft must fly at 10 800 ft. This must be the true altitude of the aircraft. This altitude must be corrected for any temperature ISA deviation and then any difference in pressure from standard (1013 hPa), to get the pressure altitude, allowing us to work out the lowest usable flight level. The first step is to determine the temperature correction. The ISA deviation is ISA -15°C. Based on the 4% rule and its calculation mentioned in the rules below, the height correction for the temperature can be calculated as follows: Height correction for temperature = 4 × (-15) × (10 800/1000) = -648 ft. The temperature correction is added to the true altitude as per the rules below, to give an indicated altitude of 11 448 ft. Next, we need to compute the pressure correction by considering the deviation from the standard mean sea level pressure of 1013 hPa: 1018 hPa - 1013 hPa = 5 hPa. Since the barometric lapse rate near the surface is 30 ft/hPa, the pressure correction can be calculated as follows: Pressure correction = (5) x 30 ft/hPa = 150 ft. This value needs to be subtracted from the indicated altitude as per the rules below: Pressure Altitude = 11 448 - 150 = 11 298 ft Since we are a VFR flight, we are required to fly at altitudes that are whole thousands plus 500 feet. The only altitude above 11 298 ft which also obeys this rule is FL115. RULES. The following rules should be considered for altimetry calculations: All calculations are based on rounded pressure values to the nearest lower hPa. The value for the barometric lapse rate between MSL and 500 hPa to be used is 30 ft/hPa as an acceptable approximation of the barometric lapse rate. To determine the true altitude/height, the following rule of thumb, called the ‘4 %-rule’, shall be used: the altitude/height changes by 4% for each 10°C temperature deviation from ISA. For simplification: Height correction for the temp = 4 × (ISA DEV) × Indicated alt/1000 = _____ ft If no further information is given, the deviation of the outside-air temperature from ISA is considered to be the same throughout the whole layer. The elevation of the aerodrome has to be taken into account. The temperature correction has to be considered for the layer between the station (usually an aerodrome) and the position of the aircraft. HIGHER PRESSURE; INDICATED ALTITUDE > PRESSURE ALTITUDE LOWER PRESSURE; INDICATED ALTITUDE < PRESSURE ALTITUDE WARMER THAN ISA; TRUE ALTITUDE > INDICATED ALTITUDE COLDER THAN ISA; TRUE ALTITUDE < INDICATED ALTITUDE DEFINITIONS. Pressure Altitude: The altimeter indication with standard pressure (1013.2 hPa) set. Indicated Altitude: The altimeter indication with local QNH set. True altitude: The actual altitude of the aircraft above mean sea level.

learning.explanation: TAS = Mach No × 38.95 √ OAT (Kelvin) In the International Standard Atmosphere (ISA), the temperature remains constant at -56.5°C above the tropopause, a level of about 36000 ft. key_points: For a climb with 3◦ path the rate of climb can be found by the formula: Rate of Climb (fpm) = 5 x Ground Speed (knots) = 5 x 210 = 1050 fpm 2
The time to climb from 3000 ft to 8000 ft is: Time to climb (min) = Height difference (ft) / ROC (fpm) = (8000 ft - 3000 ft) / 1050 fpm = 4
learning.explanation: 1. For a climb with 3◦ path the rate of climb can be found by the formula: Rate of Climb (fpm) = 5 x Ground Speed (knots) = 5 x 210 = 1050 fpm 2. The time to climb from 3000 ft to 8000 ft is: Time to climb (min) = Height difference (ft) / ROC (fpm) = (8000 ft - 3000 ft) / 1050 fpm = 4.76 min or 4 min and 46 sec. 3. content.question:
A mountain 6 011 ft AMSL will be crossed. What is the lowest VFR ICAO level the aircraft must fly to obtain a clearance of 2 000 ft? Given:
Variation: 10ºW
Aircraft's Track: 356º T
Aircraft's HDG: 355º M
QNH: 990 hPa
Assume 1 hPa = 30 ft

key_points: First considerations: To obtain a terrain clearance of 2 000 ft, the aircraft must be flown at a true altitude of = 6 011 ft + 2 000 ft = 8 011 ft When flying Flight Levels, the altimeter is set to Standard Pressure (1013 hPa)
Pressure Correction: Note: If QNH is higher than 1013 hPa => True Altitude is higher than IA
If QNH is lower than 1013 hPa => True Altitude is lower than IA
learning.explanation: First considerations: To obtain a terrain clearance of 2 000 ft, the aircraft must be flown at a true altitude of = 6 011 ft + 2 000 ft = 8 011 ft When flying Flight Levels, the altimeter is set to Standard Pressure (1013 hPa). Pressure Correction: Note: If QNH is higher than 1013 hPa => True Altitude is higher than IA. If QNH is lower than 1013 hPa => True Altitude is lower than IA. Local pressure equals 990 hPa which is lower than standard pressure by 1013 hPa - 990 hPa = 23 hPa. 23 hPa x 30 ft/hPa = 690 ft Indicated Altitude = True Altitude + Pressure Correction Indicated Altitude = 8 011 ft + 690 ft = 8 701 ft Semicircular Flight Rules: IFR flight levels/altitudes are divisible by 1 000 ft (i.e. 7 000 ft, 8 000 ft, 9 000 ft). The VFR rules of flight level and/or altitude selection is the same as IFR ones with adding 500 ft to all levels. The default worldwide semi-circular rule is the East/West orientation of the flight level parity: Your aircraft has track between 0° and 179°, your flight level or altitude must be odd; Your aircraft has track between 180° and 359°, your flight level or altitude must be even. The appropriate altitude or flight level must be determined using the magnetic track (not heading). In this case, True Track (TT) equals 356º, applying the magnetic Variation provided (10ºW), we can find the Magnetic Track (MT) Variation West, magnetic direction BEST; Variation East, Magnetic Direction LEAST. MT = 356º + 10º = 006º According to the rules shared above, an ODD flight level + 500 ft must be used: First available Flight level above 8 701 ft => FL95

content.question: Refer to VFR Chart ED-4 from the Jeppesen GSPRM 2017. A VFR flight is planned from Freiburg i. options.C: The wind farm Southwest of Schweighausen town.
options.D: The unlighted tower North of Emmendingen town.

key_points: When planning a route, the pilot will use visual check points to monitor the flight progress along a flight leg
Choice of the ground features is critical, as things that show up well on maps, do not necessarily show up well from the air
Thus, the pilot, among others, should consider: Proximity to planned track: Ground features on or close to the track are preferred
learning.explanation: When planning a route, the pilot will use visual check points to monitor the flight progress along a flight leg. Choice of the ground features is critical, as things that show up well on maps, do not necessarily show up well from the air. Thus, the pilot, among others, should consider: Proximity to planned track: Ground features on or close to the track are preferred. Size and uniqueness: Large objects with colour contrast and/or some vertical extent will be easier to identify. Time of the year: Changes in vegetation or snow cover can cause the same landscape to take on a different appearance at different times of the year. Planned Altitude: At lower levels, a selected visual check point may be hidden by high ground or only visible after the aircraft has passed over it and for a limited period of time. Some of the problems faced by a pilot during VFR navigation at lower levels are the following: The horizon may be obscured by high ground, so attitude flying is difficult. Frequent changes may be needed to maintain the correct airspeed, while climbing or descending over undulating ground. The view ahead and around is restricted by the next fold of high ground. The angle at which you are looking becomes flatter and if a feature does not have some vertical extent (such as towers and wind farms), you are unlikely to see it at low level. A selected visual check point may be hidden by high ground or only visible after the aircraft has passed over it and for a limited period of time (such as a river). Thus, towers and wind farms are the most suitable ground features for low level VFR navigation. But, among them, the best ones are those which are along the route and as close to the departure airport as possible, because the pilot will be aware of any drift or time deviation at the initial stages of the cruise phase proceeding in minor recalculations. Therefore, the visual reference landmark which best covers the forementioned criteria is the unlighted tower North of the town of Emmendingen, with elevation of 1 384 ft. content.question:
You plan to fly over high terrain of 6 240 ft where a minimum clearance altitude of 2 000 ft is required. An airport nearby at an altitude of 1 240 ft reports a QNH of 1000 hPa and the OAT is ISA -12ºC. What is the lowest usable flight level?
(Assume: 1 hPa = 30 ft)

key_points: Calculation of terrain clearance and lowest usable flight level: The aircraft must fly at 8 240 ft (6 240 ft + 2 000 ft)
This altitude must be the true altitude of the aircraft

This altitude must be corrected for any temperature ISA deviation and then any difference in pressure from standard (1013 hPa), to get the pressure altitude, allowing us to work out the lowest usable flight level
learning.explanation: Calculation of terrain clearance and lowest usable flight level: The aircraft must fly at 8 240 ft (6 240 ft + 2 000 ft). This altitude must be the true altitude of the aircraft. This altitude must be corrected for any temperature ISA deviation and then any difference in pressure from standard (1013 hPa), to get the pressure altitude, allowing us to work out the lowest usable flight level. The first step is to determine the temperature correction. The ISA deviation is ISA -12ºC. For the temperature correction, the airfield elevation must be taken into account: 8 240 ft - 1 240 ft = 7 000 ft. Based on the 4% rule and its calculation mentioned in the rules below, the height correction for the temperature can be calculated as follows: Height correction for temperature = 4 × (-12) × (7 000/1000) = -336 ft. In this case, the temperature correction is added to the true altitude as per the rules below (refer to the table below), to give an indicated altitude of ­­8 576 ft. Next, we need to compute the pressure correction by considering the deviation from the standard mean sea level pressure of 1013 hPa: 1013 hPa - 1000 hPa = 13 hPa. Since the barometric lapse rate near the surface is 30 ft/hPa, the pressure correction can be calculated as follows: Pressure correction = 13 hPa x 30 ft/hPa = 390 ft. This value needs to be added to the indicated altitude as per the rules below: Pressure Altitude = 8 576 ft + 390 ft = 8 966 ft. Thus, the Minimum Flight Level, which provides obstacle clearance, after both pressure and temperature correction, that must be selected is: FL90. RULES. The following rules should be considered for altimetry calculations: All calculations are based on rounded pressure values to the nearest lower hPa. The value for the barometric lapse rate between MSL and 500 hPa to be used is 30 ft/hPa as an acceptable approximation of the barometric lapse rate. To determine the true altitude/height, the following rule of thumb, called the ‘4 %-rule’, shall be used: the altitude/height changes by 4% for each 10°C temperature deviation from ISA. For simplification: Height correction for the temp = 4 × (ISA DEV) × Indicated alt/1000 = ___ ft If no further information is given, the deviation of the outside-air temperature from ISA is considered to be the same throughout the whole layer. The elevation of the aerodrome has to be taken into account. The temperature correction has to be considered for the layer between the station (usually an aerodrome) and the position of the aircraft. HIGHER PRESSURE; INDICATED ALTITUDE > PRESSURE ALTITUDE LOWER PRESSURE; INDICATED ALTITUDE < PRESSURE ALTITUDE WARMER THAN ISA; TRUE ALTITUDE > INDICATED ALTITUDE COLDER THAN ISA; TRUE ALTITUDE < INDICATED ALTITUDE DEFINITIONS. Pressure Altitude: The altimeter indication with standard pressure (1013.2 hPa) set. Indicated Altitude: The altimeter indication with local QNH set. True altitude: The actual altitude of the aircraft above mean sea level.

content.question: A VFR flight is planned from aerodrome A to aerodrome B on a 085° track. What would be an appropriate Flight Level for this route?

key_points: In order to apply vertical separation, the ICAO VFR Semi-Circular Rule must be followed
The ICAO VFR semi-circular rule can be derived, which permits the selection of FLs, in accordance with aircraft’s magnetic track
Tracks are specified as being either ‘eastbound’ or ‘westbound’
learning.explanation: In order to apply vertical separation, the ICAO VFR Semi-Circular Rule must be followed. The ICAO VFR semi-circular rule can be derived, which permits the selection of FLs, in accordance with aircraft’s magnetic track. Tracks are specified as being either ‘eastbound’ or ‘westbound’. Eastbound tracks are 000°M - 179°M inclusive, and westbound, 180°M - 359°M inclusive. For the eastbound magnetic tracks we select Odd Fls + 500 ft (35,55,75, etc.). For the westbound magnetic tracks we select Even FLs + 500 ft (25,45,65, etc.). The question does not specify if the track is magnetic or true, but whichever the variation could be, the track still remains eastbound. Therefore, according to the ICAO VFR semi-circular rule, the FL that must be selected for 085° track is FL55.

learning.explanation: Firstly, find the exact position of the two aerodromes, using the coordinates given, draw a straight line as a route between them and examine each statement carefully. Altitude selection: Before the route is recorded on the flight plan, we need to consider the altitude to fly at. The Minimum Grid Area Altitudes along the route are 5 400 ft, 7 200 ft and 4 100 ft. For this VFR flight, the minimum safe altitude along the whole route is 7 200 ft. But, we have to also consider the ICAO VFR cruising altitudes and select an appropriate altitude for this easterly magnetic track. According to the ICAO VFR semi-circular rule, for an easterly magnetic track, Odd FLs/Altitudes + 500 ft must be followed (3 500 ft, 5 500 ft, 7 500 ft, etc.). So, a cruise altitude of 7 500 ft can be followed, which apart from being according to the ICAO rule, it provides enough obstacle clearance too. In portions of the whole route, a lower altitude could be flown, 5 500 ft, but with less vertical obstacle clearance provided, probably poor comms signal and encountered turbulence. Ground feature selection: Line features, such as highways, which cross vertically the intended track are highly recommended as ground features for navigation in VFR flights. Both Highways, A3 and A92, as line features, are very helpful for groundspeed and timing checks, because they both cross vertically the track. But among them, the A3 highway is more preferred since it is almost halfway. Of course, the Power plant at Vilshofen (1 593 ft) could be selected as a VFR checkpoint, since it covers the criteria that should be considered for a VFR ground feature selection, but the question asks for the best. NavAid selection: Between the LNZ and FRE VOR/DME, the former is the best to tune to, even just after take-off (if both relief and VOR’s range permit), since it easily leads to the destination, almost directly, with an insignificant course deviation.

content.question: You want to plan a VFR flight within a controlled airspace using your GNSS flight plan as a back-up navigation method. Which of the following are best suited as significant points for entering into your GNSS flight plan as VFR waypoints using a distance and bearing?

key_points: The question is poorly worded as none of the answers in this question fit the criteria for visual fix points that can be defined by a distance and bearing from a known point, nor are they suitable as known points for creating a distance and bearing to a VFR waypoint
The only possible known point for defining a VFR waypoint via bearing and distance is the airport reference point (ARP)
An airport reference point (ARP) is a known and well-defined location on an airport used as a reference for navigation purposes
learning.explanation: The question is poorly worded as none of the answers in this question fit the criteria for visual fix points that can be defined by a distance and bearing from a known point, nor are they suitable as known points for creating a distance and bearing to a VFR waypoint. The only possible known point for defining a VFR waypoint via bearing and distance is the airport reference point (ARP). An airport reference point (ARP) is a known and well-defined location on an airport used as a reference for navigation purposes. Using the ARP as a waypoint in a GNSS flight plan provides a reliable and accurate navigation aid for VFR flights, especially when flying within controlled airspace. This is because the ARP is precisely located on aviation charts and is well-known to air traffic controllers, making it easier to communicate your position to ATC if necessary. Power lines, major cities and large towns, and coastlines may be visually identifiable landmarks that can assist with navigation, but they are not as precise and reliable as using an airport reference point. Additionally, power lines may not always be visible, and coastlines can be affected by changing weather conditions, tides, and other factors, making them less reliable as navigation aids. Major cities and large towns can be useful as general orientation points but may not provide the necessary precision needed for accurate navigation within a controlled airspace.

key_points: One of the methods used to solve this question is to calculate True Altitude based on the provided Pressure Altitude - by correcting it for QNH deviation and for Temperature deviation
Note that in this case, temperature = ISA, therefore we can disregard the latter
Adjust for QNH deviation If QNH is higher than 1013 hPa => Indicated Altitude is lower than True Altitude
learning.explanation: One of the methods used to solve this question is to calculate True Altitude based on the provided Pressure Altitude - by correcting it for QNH deviation and for Temperature deviation. Note that in this case, temperature = ISA, therefore we can disregard the latter. Adjust for QNH deviation If QNH is higher than 1013 hPa => Indicated Altitude is lower than True Altitude. If QNH is lower than 1013 hPa => Indicated Altitude is higher than True Altitude. 1023 – 1013 = 10 hPa 10 hPa x 30 ft = 300 ft With regards to this question, QNH is 10 hPa higher than standard, therefore, True altitude is 30 hPa higher than IA => 7500 ft + 300 ft = 7 800 ft. When you climb from the airport with an elevation of 1 500 ft to True Altitude of 7 800 ft, you will climb 7800 - 1500 = 6300 ft.

content.question: An aircraft is flying at FL180, OAT -11°C, QNH 1003. What is the true altitude?

key_points: True altitude calculation from a Flight Level: In this question, we are given a pressure altitude (in the form of a flight level) and are asked for the terrain clearance, therefore we need to determine the corresponding true altitude
The first step is to compute the pressure correction by considering the deviation from the standard mean sea level pressure of 1013 hPa: 1013 hPa - 1003 hPa = 10 hPa
Since the barometric lapse rate near the surface is 30 ft/hPa, the pressure correction can be calculated as follows: Pressure correction = 10 hPa x 30 ft/hPa = ­­­300 ft
learning.explanation: True altitude calculation from a Flight Level: In this question, we are given a pressure altitude (in the form of a flight level) and are asked for the terrain clearance, therefore we need to determine the corresponding true altitude. The first step is to compute the pressure correction by considering the deviation from the standard mean sea level pressure of 1013 hPa: 1013 hPa - 1003 hPa = 10 hPa. Since the barometric lapse rate near the surface is 30 ft/hPa, the pressure correction can be calculated as follows: Pressure correction = 10 hPa x 30 ft/hPa = ­­­300 ft. This value needs to be subtracted from the pressure altitude as per the rules below: Indicated altitude = 18 000 ft - 300 ft = 17 700 ft. To determine the temperature correction, it is necessary to have knowledge of the ISA air temperature for the given flight level/altitude (FL250). In the International Standard Atmosphere (ISA), the air temperature at sea level is 15ºC, and the temperature lapse rate is -2ºC/1 000 ft. The formula to calculate the ISA temperature is therefore: ISA temperature = 15ºC - (18 000/1 000) x 2, giving an ISA temperature of ­­­-21 ºC. The actual outside air temperature is ­­­-11 ºC, which means we have an ISA deviation of ISA +10ºC. Next, we need to determine the temperature correction. The ISA deviation is ISA +10ºC. Based on the 4% rule and its calculation mentioned in the rules below, the height correction for the temperature can be calculated as follows: Height correction for temperature = 4 × (+10) × (17 700/1000) = + 708 ft. The temperature correction is added to the indicated altitude as per the rules below, to give a true altitude of 17 700 ft + 708 ft = 18 408 ft RULES. The following rules should be considered for altimetry calculations: All calculations are based on rounded pressure values to the nearest lower hPa. The value for the barometric lapse rate between MSL and 500 hPa to be used is 30 ft/hPa as an acceptable approximation of the barometric lapse rate (if not provided by the question). To determine the true altitude/height, the following rule of thumb, called the ‘4 %-rule’, shall be used: the altitude/height changes by 4% for each 10°C temperature deviation from ISA. For simplification: Height correction for the temp = 4 × (ISA DEV) × Indicated alt/1000 = ___ ft If no further information is given, the deviation of the outside-air temperature from ISA is considered to be the same throughout the whole layer. The elevation of the aerodrome has to be taken into account. The temperature correction has to be considered for the layer between the station (usually an aerodrome) and the position of the aircraft. HIGHER PRESSURE; INDICATED ALTITUDE > PRESSURE ALTITUDE LOWER PRESSURE; INDICATED ALTITUDE < PRESSURE ALTITUDE WARMER THAN ISA; TRUE ALTITUDE > INDICATED ALTITUDE COLDER THAN ISA; TRUE ALTITUDE < INDICATED ALTITUDE DEFINITIONS. Pressure Altitude: The altimeter indication with standard pressure (1013.2 hPa) set. Indicated Altitude: The altimeter indication with local QNH set. True altitude: The actual altitude of the aircraft above mean sea level.

content.question: What is an advantage of using GNSS/FMC equipment in flight?

options.A: Limitations imposed by the Instrument Flight Rules can be disregarded in uncontrolled airspace.
options.B: Visual Meteorological conditions limitations are reduced.
options.C: Additional aeronautical information can be stored in the database.
options.D: Great circle routes CANNOT be flown without GNSS/FMC equipment.

key_points: All modern transport aircraft will have Flight Management Computers (FMCs) fitted

Although the primary navigation input into the FMC comes from GNSS, it is usual for the FMC to compile and compare the GNSS position with other navigation systems, such as IRS, DME, VOR and even on some types, such as A380, with NDB
The GNSS stands for Global Navigation Satellite System
learning.explanation: All modern transport aircraft will have Flight Management Computers (FMCs) fitted. Although the primary navigation input into the FMC comes from GNSS, it is usual for the FMC to compile and compare the GNSS position with other navigation systems, such as IRS, DME, VOR and even on some types, such as A380, with NDB. The GNSS stands for Global Navigation Satellite System. FMCs contain two main databases, a navigation database and a performance one. The navigation database includes not only the position of navigation beacons, waypoints and airways, but also SIDs, STARs, approach procedures, runway lengths and minimum altitudes. The FMC will automatically calculate and display tracks and leg distances. It has also the ability to calculate speeds to arrive over a waypoint at a defined time, a selection known as RTA (Required Time of Arrival), as well as many other computational functions such as automatic fuel calculations. According to the Learning Objective 033.02.01.07.08, the advantages of a Global Navigation Satellite System/Flight Management Computer (GNSS/FMC) equipment are: Automatic calculation and display of tracks and leg distances Additional route information in the database (minimum altitudes, approach procedures) Time and fuel estimates over waypoints Ability to adjust speed to arrive over a waypoint at a defined time Time and fuel revisions based on predicted and actual wind

An aircraft is routing in IMC towards Aberdeen aerodrome from the south-east, where the Minimum Sector Altitude (MSA) is 2500 feet. While routing towards the ATF NDB at 3000 feet on the Aberdeen QNH, the following instruction is received by the pilot from the Approach Radar controller:

options.B: Maintain heading and altitude, and request new descent instructions, because 2300 feet is below MSA.
options.C: Turn left to head 285°(M) and descend to 2300 feet. The minimum radar vectoring altitude may be below MSA.

key_points: Radar vectoring means giving the pilot specific headings to maintain the desired track
When "under vectors" or "under radar control", it means that a radar control service is being provided, i
e
learning.explanation: Radar vectoring means giving the pilot specific headings to maintain the desired track. When "under vectors" or "under radar control", it means that a radar control service is being provided, i.e. the PIC must do what he is told by the radar unit and the ATC assumes responsibility for separation and terrain clearance in flight, providing bearing, distance and height information on known conflicting traffic. Some services will also provide advisory avoiding action. Thus, the PIC when "under vectors", should follow the ATC's instructions. In a radar environment, heading information given by the pilot and heading instructions given by the controllers are in degrees magnetic. Minimum Radar Vectoring Altitude (MRVA), also known as Minimum Vectoring Altitude (MVA), is the lowest alltitude, expressed in feet AMSL, to which a radar controller may issue aircraft altitude clearances during vectoring. MRVA allows the ATC to vector and descent an aircraft below MSA to achieve VFR or to join a procedure. Therefore, the pilot should turn left to head 285°(M) and descend to 2300 feet. The minimum radar vectoring altitude may be below MSA.

Which of the following is(are) Type A approach(es)?
1. ILS with DH: 270 ft
2. VOR with MDH: 250 ft
3. VOR with MDH: 200 ft
4. ILS with DH: 140 ft

key_points: According to ICAO Annex 6, Annex 10 and Annex 14, there are two types of classification for approach operations, dependent upon the achieved minima at the end of the approach: Type A: may be either 2D or 3D operations; 2D will only have a lateral path defined for the approach operation where 3D will have both a lateral and vertical path defined for that operation
A Type A operation will permit aircraft operations down to a minimum height or altitude of 250 ft
All NPAs and Approcahes with Vertical guidance (APV) using Barometric altimetry are Type A approach operations
learning.explanation: According to ICAO Annex 6, Annex 10 and Annex 14, there are two types of classification for approach operations, dependent upon the achieved minima at the end of the approach: Type A: may be either 2D or 3D operations; 2D will only have a lateral path defined for the approach operation where 3D will have both a lateral and vertical path defined for that operation. A Type A operation will permit aircraft operations down to a minimum height or altitude of 250 ft. All NPAs and Approcahes with Vertical guidance (APV) using Barometric altimetry are Type A approach operations. Type B: are 3D operations; a lateral and vertical path is defined and guidance along this path is provided either from GPS with SBAS (APV SBAS) or by a precision approach system. Thus, Type A approaches are 1. ILS with DH > 250 ft and 2. VOR with MDH = 250 ft. Important Note: "3. VOR with MDH = 200 ft" is not possible as VOR/DME approaches have a system minima of 250ft, so cannot have a MDH below this value. This makes it not possible as an approach at all, and could potentially make this question worthy of an appeal, as it is misleading. Any further exam feedback about this can be put in the comments or sent to info@atplquestions.com, thank you.

content.question:
(Refer to SANTORINI - Chart 10-2A from Jeppesen GSPRM 2017).
What is a correct description of how a descent must be flown while following STAR PEXAN 1C at Santorini, Greece?

options.A: You should proceed at or below 7 000 ft until reaching PEXAN.
options.B: When passing PEXAN inbound, you may descend to 3 000 ft.
options.C: Lowest altitude before passing PEXAN 7 000 ft.
options.D: MSA in the area will be 3 600 ft.

key_points: ”You should proceed at or below 7000 feet until reaching PEXAN” Incorrect
7 000 ft is the Minimum En-route Altitude (MEA) between NETIS and PEXAN
Put simply, the MEA is the lowest altitude to be flown in an airspace structure which assures obstacle clearance requirements
learning.explanation: ”You should proceed at or below 7000 feet until reaching PEXAN” Incorrect. 7 000 ft is the Minimum En-route Altitude (MEA) between NETIS and PEXAN. Put simply, the MEA is the lowest altitude to be flown in an airspace structure which assures obstacle clearance requirements. From NETIS to PEXAN, the aircraft must fly above 7 000 ft. “Lowest altitude before passing PEXAN 7000 feet” Correct. See above. “When passing PEXAN inbound, you may descend to 3000 feet” Incorrect. The Minimum En-route Altitude (MEA) between PEXAN and MIL is 3 500 ft which means that the aircraft can descend from 7 000 ft but it must fly above 3 500 ft. “MSA in the area will be 3 600 ft” Incorrect. The Minimum Sector Altitude (MSA) is the lowest altitude which may be used which will provide a minimum clearance of 300 m (1 000 ft) within a 25 NM radius from the navigational facility. In this case, MSA can be read left of Santorini airport. MSA is 3 500 ft and not 3 600 ft.

options.C: The RNAV STAR overlay will follow a different route from the conventional STAR procedure.

learning.explanation: An approach can be performed using the overlay method with charts such as this conventional approach (NDB) chart. This chart observes two different flight paths; CDFA (solid line) and non-CDFA (dashed). In addition, the missed approach point is indicated on the chart for both approach types. When in doubt when approaching using the overlay method, rely on conventional methods. The conventional Standard Arrival Route procedures (STARs) use ground navigational aids, while the RNAV STARs use Fly-by and Fly-over waypoints and are followed by the FMS. RNAV equipment tends to be more accurate than basic fixing and can be based on either VOR/DME information, satellite systems, inertial systems or combinations of these. An RNAV STAR overlay is a traditional STAR that allows pilots to use GNSS equipment to fly existing, conventional STAR procedures, without replacing it. It follows the same route as the conventional procedure, with waypoints defined by coordinates instead of bearings and distances from ground navigation aids. In most cases, each ground navigation aid or intersection point of the conventional STAR, corresponds to an RNAV waypoint. Additionally, some RNAV waypoints (Fly-by or Fly-over) may be added, non-existing in the conventional STAR, to facilitate the turns. An RNAV STAR overlay may be either shorter or longer in distance than an RNAV STAR, depending on the design.
